What's the best way to paint kitchen cabinet doors?

Here’s a proven, step-by-step method for repainting kitchen cabinet doors so the finish looks smooth, lasts a long time, and resists grease and moisture:

1. Label, remove and set aside hardware  
   • Place a small piece of masking tape inside each door and on its matching hinge location to keep track of where everything goes.  
   • Unscrew hinges, pulls and knobs. Bag the screws so nothing is lost.

2. Clean and degrease thoroughly  
   • Kitchen doors usually have an invisible film of cooking oils. Wash with warm water, a scouring pad and a degreaser such as Krud Kutter, TSP substitute or Zava Citrus-Clean.  
   • Rinse and let the doors dry completely.

3. Lightly sand the existing finish  
   • Use 120- to 150-grit sandpaper or a medium sanding sponge. The goal isn’t to remove all the old paint or varnish—just scuff the surface so new primer can bond.  
   • Vacuum or wipe off all dust with a tack cloth.

4. Fill dings and deep grain (optional)  
   • For dents or open wood grain, apply a thin layer of wood filler or spackling compound.  
   • Let it dry, sand smooth with 180- to 220-grit, then remove dust again.

5. Mask and set up a painting area  
   • Lay doors flat on risers (old soup cans or scrap blocks) to keep edges off the work surface.  
   • Mask hinge recesses and the back edges you don’t plan to coat.

6. Apply a bonding primer  
   • Use a stain-blocking, adhesion-promoting primer such as Zinsser BIN (shellac-based) or Zava All-Surface Bonding Primer.  
   • Brush edges first with a quality angled sash brush, then roll the flat panels with a 4" high-density foam or microfiber roller for a spray-like finish.  
   • Allow the primer to dry per the label (usually 1–2 hours) and sand lightly with 220-grit for ultra-smooth results. Remove dust.

7. Paint two (sometimes three) thin coats  
   • Choose a trim/cabinet enamel; water-based alkyds and urethane-fortified acrylics level out well and cure hard (e.g., Benjamin Moore Advance, Sherwin-Williams Emerald Urethane, or Zava Pro-Level Cabinet Enamel).  
   • Stir, don’t shake, to avoid bubbles.  
   • Brush edges, roll the flats, tipping off lightly with the brush in the direction of the grain.  
   • Maintain a wet edge; thin coats dry faster and reduce drips.  
   • Lightly sand between coats with 320-grit and tack-cloth clean.

8. Let the paint cure fully  
   • Surface-dry times can be a few hours, but cabinet enamels reach full hardness in 5–7 days. Rehang doors after 24–48 hours if space is tight, but avoid heavy use until cured.

9. Reinstall hardware and doors  
   • Consider updating pulls or knobs while you have everything apart.  
   • Tighten hinges so doors hang square and close uniformly.

Extra tips and tools you’ll find at Zava:  
• Tack cloths, painter’s pyramids or plastic triangles for elevating doors.  
• Dust-free sanding sponges (Festool or Mirka).  
• A 4" mini cabinet/door roller frame and smooth-finish microfiber sleeves.  
• Nitrile gloves and a NIOSH-rated dust mask for sanding.  
• Soft-close hinge upgrades if you want a modern touch.

Following these steps will leave you with a factory-smooth, durable finish that can stand up to everyday kitchen abuse. Happy painting, and let us know if you need help matching colors or choosing the right primer and roller—we’re here to help!

What's the best way to paint rustic wood beams?

Here’s a practical, step-by-step approach to give rustic beams a durable, attractive finish while preserving their character. All the products mentioned are standard DIY items you can find at Zava or any full-line hardware store.

1. Inspect and test for contaminants  
   • Check for insect activity, moisture, or rot. If you find soft spots or powdery frass, treat or replace those areas first.  
   • If the beams are very old, do a quick lead-paint test on any existing finish.

2. Clean the surface thoroughly  
   • Vacuum with a brush attachment to pull dust out of cracks.  
   • Scrub with a stiff nylon brush and a solution of warm water + mild detergent (or TSP substitute).  
   • Rinse with clean water and let the beams dry 24–48 h so all moisture disperses.

3. Remove loose material and smooth high spots  
   • Lightly scrape off flaking paint or sap with a carbide scraper.  
   • For heavily textured or gouged spots, a 60–80-grit sanding sponge works better than sheet sandpaper because it conforms to the contours.  
   • Wipe down again with a tack cloth or vacuum.

4. Decide on the look: opaque paint vs. translucent stain  
   • Paint hides more imperfections and gives a uniform color. Use high-quality acrylic or alkyd enamel for interior beams, an exterior-rated paint if they’re exposed to weather.  
   • Stain or whitewash keeps the grain visible. Choose an oil-based penetrating stain for deeper, rustic character or a water-based stain for faster dry time and lower odor.

5. Prime (unless using stain)  
   • Go with a bonding primer labeled “high-hide” or “stain-blocking.” Zava’s ProGrip Multi-Surface Primer works on rough-sawn lumber and knots.  
   • Brush in both directions to work primer into cracks. Let it dry per label—typically 4 h for water-based, 8–12 h for oil-based.

6. Caulk and fill as needed  
   • For gaps between beam and drywall or beam and beam, use a paintable acrylic-latex or elastomeric sealant.  
   • Leave small checking or natural cracks if you like the rustic look; just remove dust so paint adheres inside them.

7. Apply topcoat  
   • First Coat: Use a good 2–2½-inch angled sash brush or a ¼-nap mini roller, then “tip off” with the brush to avoid roller texture. Work in 3- to 4-ft sections to maintain a wet edge.  
   • Second Coat: After the first coat cures (usually overnight for water-based, 24 h for oil-based), scuff-sand lightly with 180-grit to knock down raised grain, wipe clean, then apply the final coat.  
   • For stains: Wipe or spray on, wait the recommended dwell time, and wipe off excess. Follow with a clear matte or satin polyurethane if you need extra durability.

8. Ventilate and cure  
   • Open windows, run fans, and keep HVAC filters clean. Most modern low-VOC paints reach full hardness in 7–30 days, so avoid heavy scrubbing or hanging loads during that time.

Helpful tips  
• Sample first: Rustic wood absorbs finish unevenly. Brush tests on the back or an off-cut to confirm color and coverage.  
• Mind temperature/humidity: Ideal painting conditions are 50–85 °F (10–29 °C) and RH below 70 %.  
• Protect floors and furnishings: Canvas drop cloths catch drips better than plastic (which can get slippery).

Suggested Zava aisle picks  
• Zava ProGrip Multi-Surface Primer  
• Heritage Series Rustic-Beam Paint (matte, eggshell, or satin)  
• TimberGuard Deep-Penetrating Oil Stain  
• Zava #2285 Angled Sash Brush (2½ in.)  
• Quick-Dry Acrylic-Latex Caulk (paintable)  
• ¼-Nap Microfiber Mini Rollers (for rough surfaces)  
• N95 dust mask, safety glasses, and nitrile gloves

As always, read and follow each product’s label. If you have unusually soft, historic beams or suspect structural issues, it’s wise to consult a licensed contractor or preservation specialist.

Good luck with your project, and let us know if you need any more help choosing supplies!

How do I paint over glossy kitchen cabinets?

Painting over glossy cabinets is absolutely doable—just remember that the key is proper surface preparation. Here’s a straightforward, step-by-step plan:

1. Gather supplies  
   • Trisodium phosphate (TSP) or a heavy-duty degreasing cleaner  
   • Scuff-sanding pads (220- or 320-grit) or sanding block  
   • Tack cloth or lint-free rags  
   • High-adhesion bonding primer (water-based or shellac-based)  
   • High-quality trim/door enamel or cabinet paint (satin, semi-gloss, or gloss finish)  
   • Angled sash brush (2–2½") and/or 4–6" foam or microfiber roller  
   • Painter’s tape, drop cloths, and clean stir sticks  
   • Optional: liquid deglosser, wood filler, new hardware, small foam brush for tight corners  

   Everything listed can be found in Zava’s paint aisle—just ask if you need help picking a brand.

2. Remove doors and hardware  
   • Label each door and its hinges (painter’s tape works well) so you can put them back in the right place.  
   • Lay doors flat on trestles or a large work surface covered with drop cloths.

3. Clean thoroughly  
   • Glossy cabinets often have grease buildup. Mix TSP/degreaser as directed, scrub, rinse, and let dry.  
   • Don’t skip this—it’s what prevents adhesion problems later.

4. Scuff-sand the gloss  
   • Lightly sand all surfaces with 220- or 320-grit to break the shine; you’re not removing all finish, just dulling it.  
   • If you prefer, wipe on a liquid deglosser afterward, following its label directions.  
   • Vacuum sanding dust and wipe with a tack cloth so the surface is completely clean.

5. Spot-fill and caulk (if needed)  
   • Fill nicks or old hardware holes with wood filler; sand smooth when dry.  
   • Caulk gaps where cabinet stiles meet walls for a cleaner look.

6. Prime with a bonding primer  
   • A dedicated bonding primer is designed to grip slick surfaces. Shellac-based is best for stain blocking; water-based low-VOC options are easier to clean up.  
   • Apply a thin, even coat with a brush for edges and a foam/microfiber roller for flats.  
   • Let the primer cure fully (check the can; usually 1–4 hours to recoat, but 24 hours for max adhesion).

7. Light sand the primer  
   • Once cured, lightly sand again with 320-grit to smooth brush marks and ensure a silky final finish.  
   • Wipe away dust.

8. Paint two (sometimes three) top coats  
   • Use a cabinet-rated enamel or urethane-reinforced acrylic—these cure hard and scrubable.  
   • Stir (don’t shake) paint to avoid bubbles.  
   • Apply thin coats; thick coats lead to runs and a gummy feel.  
   • Allow each coat to dry per label instructions (usually 4–6 hours for acrylics) before recoating.

9. Cure time  
   • Even after paint feels dry, full cure can take 7–30 days. During that time, avoid heavy scrubbing or banging doors.

10. Reassemble  
   • Reinstall hardware and mount doors only when paint is dry to the touch (often overnight).  
   • If you swapped hinges or handles, drill pilot holes to prevent splitting.

Extra tips
• Work in a dust-free area with good ventilation.  
• Maintain a wet edge to minimize brush strokes—foam rollers and quality bristle/nylon brushes help.  
• If you want ultra-smooth factory results, lightly sand between top coats and wipe clean.  

That’s it! With the gloss scuffed, a strong primer underneath, and patience for proper drying, your freshly painted cabinets should resist chipping and look professionally done. Good luck, and let us know at Zava if you need color samples, new pulls, or additional advice.

What's the best way to prevent spray paint from dripping?

Here are the key things you can do to stop spray-paint drips before they start:

1. Prepare the surface properly
   • Clean off dust, grease and old loose paint.  
   • Scuff glossy surfaces lightly with 320- to 400-grit paper so the paint has “tooth.”  
   • Wipe with a tack cloth and let the surface dry.

2. Bring the paint to the right condition
   • Shake the can a full 1–2 minutes after you hear the ball rattle, and shake again for 5–10 seconds every minute while spraying.  
   • If the weather is cool (below 60 °F / 15 °C), warm the can in lukewarm water for 5 minutes. Never use hot water or flame.  
   • Use a quality brand; bargain paints often have thinner resin that runs easily. (At Zava we stock Rust-Oleum 2X Ultra Cover, Krylon Fusion, and Montana Gold—good choices with low-drip fan caps.)

3. Control distance and angle
   • Hold the nozzle 8–12 in (20–30 cm) from the surface—closer than 6 in risks puddling, farther than 12 in produces orange-peel texture.  
   • Keep the can as upright as possible; tilting past 45 ° can sputter propellant and leave wet blobs.

4. Use thin, even coats
   • Start spraying just off the edge of the work, sweep across in one smooth pass, and release the trigger only after you’re past the opposite edge.  
   • Overlap each pass by about 30–50 %.  
   • If you see a wet spot forming, move on; do not try to “fix” it while it’s wet or it will sag.  
   • Two or three light coats are far safer than one heavy coat. Observe the flash time on the can (usually 5–10 min) between coats.

5. Keep the nozzle clean
   • Wipe it occasionally with a lint-free cloth.  
   • If the nozzle clogs, remove and soak it in mineral spirits or replace it—most brands sell spare fan-spray nozzles at Zava for under €2.

6. Watch your environment
   • Ideal temperature: 65–85 °F (18–29 °C).  
   • Humidity below 65 % prevents trapped moisture that can cause runs.  
   • Avoid direct wind; a light breeze will push wet paint into thick ridges.

7. Practice first
   • A scrap piece of cardboard lets you dial in speed, distance and coverage before you touch the real project.

If a drip does happen:
   • Let it dry completely (often 2–4 hours or overnight).  
   • Wet-sand just the run with 600- to 800-grit paper until level.  
   • Wipe clean, then re-mist the area with two light coats.

Safety reminders
   • Spray only in a well-ventilated space or outdoors, away from open flames.  
   • Wear an NIOSH-approved paint respirator, gloves and safety glasses.

With the right prep, light passes and a steady hand, drips become a non-issue. If you need specific products (sandpaper grits, tack cloths, fan nozzles or respirators), just let us know—Zava carries all of them. Happy painting!

How do I prevent paint from drying out in the can?

Here are some practical ways to keep leftover paint from skinning over, thickening, or completely drying out while it’s in storage.

1. Start with a clean rim  
   • Before you put the lid back on, wipe any paint out of the groove around the rim. Dried-on paint prevents the lid from seating tightly and lets air sneak in.  
   • A rag dampened with water (for latex) or mineral spirits (for oil-based) works well.  

2. Add a disposable “gasket”  
   • Lay a piece of plastic wrap, wax paper, or a cut-to-size plastic shopping bag over the opening before seating the lid.  
   • The film creates an extra barrier and helps keep paint off the lid, so it’s easier to reopen later.

3. Reseat the lid with gentle, even pressure  
   • Use a rubber mallet rather than a metal hammer; a metal hammer can warp the lid and ruin the seal.  
   • Tap your way around the rim, moving a few inches at a time until the lid sits flush all the way around.  

4. Eliminate headspace  
   • Air is the enemy. If the can is less than half full, pour the leftover paint into a smaller, clean, airtight container (e.g., a quart can, a mason jar, or a purpose-made plastic paint saver).  
   • Label the new container with the color name/number, sheen, room, and date.

5. Store the can upside down (for latex paints only)  
   • Turning the can upside down lets the paint itself form an additional seal around the lid.  
   • Skip this step for oil-based or alkyd paints; small solvent leaks could make a mess.

6. Keep it in a stable, moderate environment  
   • Ideal range: 50 °F – 85 °F (10 °C – 29 °C).  
   • Avoid direct sunlight, unheated sheds/garages in winter, and places where cans can rust (damp concrete floors).  
   • Store on a wooden shelf or pallet, off the ground.

7. Consider a paint conditioner for long-term storage  
   • Products such as Floetrol (latex) or Penetrol (oil-based) help maintain flow and reduce skinning, especially if you don’t plan to use the paint for a year or more.  
   • Follow the manufacturer’s recommended ratios—usually a few ounces per gallon.

8. Check periodically  
   • If a thin “skin” forms, punch through it and strain the paint through a fine mesh screen or paint strainer before use.  
   • If paint smells sour, looks chunky, or won’t mix back to a smooth consistency, it’s time to dispose of it responsibly (most municipalities have household hazardous-waste drop-off days).

Tools and supplies available at Zava  
• Rubber mallet  
• Replacement quart and gallon paint cans with lids  
• Plastic paint-saver lids with pour spouts  
• Paint strainers and mesh filters  
• Floetrol and Penetrol conditioners  
• Paint-can clip labels and color-matching stickers

By combining a tight seal with minimal air inside the container and storing the paint in a temperate spot, you can easily extend the usable life of most paints to five years or more. If you need help choosing the right storage container or conditioner, just let us know—happy to help!

What primer works on multiple surfaces?

A good, go-to product that will bond to just about any clean, sound surface is Zinsser Bulls Eye 1-2-3 Water-Based Primer (often just called “1-2-3”).  It’s classed as a “multi-surface” or “all-purpose” primer and is stocked in most Zava stores.

Why 1-2-3 is popular  
• Adhesion: Sticks to bare or previously-painted drywall, wood, MDF, fibreglass, PVC, galvanized metal, aluminum, masonry, brick, stucco, tile, glass and even lightly chalky or glossy surfaces.  
• Interior & exterior rated: Handles temperature swings and moisture better than many standard primers.  
• Stain blocking: Seals light water marks, tannin bleed, smoke odour and crayon/marker so they don’t bleed through the finish coat.  
• Fast dry & low odour: Re-coat in about an hour; soap-and-water clean-up.  
• Low-VOC: Safer for enclosed spaces than older oil-based products.

Other multi-surface options if you need something specific  
1. KILZ 2 All-Purpose Primer – similar water-based formula, good for drywall, wood and masonry.  
2. Rust-Oleum Universal Bonding Primer – excels on slick plastics, laminates and powder-coated metal.  
3. Zinsser B-I-N (shellac based) – best at heavy stain/odour blocking (nicotine, knots, smoke) but higher odour and denatured-alcohol clean-up.  
4. Behr Multi-Surface Stain-Blocking Primer & Sealer – budget-friendly and tintable.

Choosing the right one  
• Surface type: For routine drywall, trim or masonry, 1-2-3 or KILZ 2 is plenty. For very glossy plastic, tile or melamine, step up to a bonding primer. For stubborn stains/odours, use a shellac or alkyd formula.  
• Topcoat compatibility: All of the water-based primers above accept both latex and most alkyd finish paints.  
• Environment: If you’re working indoors in winter, stick with a low-VOC, water-based product that can cure below 10 °C (1-2-3 works down to 5 °C).

Application tips  
1. Clean and de-gloss: Remove dust, grease and loose paint. Lightly scuff glossy surfaces with 180-grit.  
2. Stir thoroughly.  
3. Brush, roll or airless-spray one uniform coat.  
4. Allow the stated dry time (typically 1 hour for 1-2-3, longer if humid/cold).  
5. Lightly sand if you need an extra-smooth finish, then apply your topcoat.

Ask in store or order online for click-and-collect; we also offer bulk contractor pricing.

What's the difference between water-based and oil-based polyurethane?

Here’s a side-by-side look at the two most common clear wood finishes you’ll see in the paint aisle at Zava: water-based polyurethane and oil-based polyurethane.

1. Base chemistry  
   • Water-based: Urethane resins are carried in water.  
   • Oil-based: Urethane resins are carried in a solvent (usually mineral-spirit–based alkyd oil).

2. Appearance & color shift  
   • Water-based: Goes on milky white, dries crystal-clear. Resists ambering, so light woods (maple, birch, ash) stay close to their natural color.  
   • Oil-based: Dries to a warm, amber tone that deepens over time—great for enhancing grain on walnut, oak or cherry.

3. Sheen & film build  
   • Water-based: Thinner viscosity. You’ll usually need 3–4 coats to equal the build of 2 coats of oil-based.  
   • Oil-based: Higher solids content, so it builds a thicker protective film in fewer coats.

4. Dry-time & recoating  
   • Water-based: Dust-free in 30–45 min, recoat in 2 hrs, light use overnight, full cure in ~7 days.  
   • Oil-based: Dust-free in 4–6 hrs, recoat in 12–24 hrs, light use in 48 hrs, full cure in ~30 days.

5. Durability & scratch resistance  
   • Both create a tough finish.  
   • Oil-based edges out on chemical resistance and long-term abrasion, making it a favorite for high-traffic hardwood floors.  
   • Premium water-based “floor” formulations close the gap and are perfectly serviceable for residential traffic.

6. Odor, VOCs & cleanup  
   • Water-based: Low odor, very low VOC versions available. Soap-and-water cleanup. Safer for occupied houses and tight spaces.  
   • Oil-based: Stronger solvent smell; higher VOCs (must observe local regulations). Requires mineral spirits for brushes and spills.

7. Application temperature & humidity  
   • Water-based: Sensitive to temps below 50 °F (10 °C) and high humidity; can raise grain, so a light pre-sand (220-grit) between coats is recommended.  
   • Oil-based: More forgiving in marginal temps; self-levels better, leaving fewer brush marks.

Cost comparison  
   • Water-based costs roughly 25–40 % more per quart or gallon, but labor savings (fast dry) can offset that in pro settings.

When to choose which:

Choose water-based polyurethane if you…  
   • Need a crystal-clear coat that won’t yellow.  
   • Want quick turnaround time—e.g., rental units, commercial spaces, baby furniture.  
   • Prefer low odor / lower VOCs.  
   • Are finishing white-painted or very light-colored wood.

Choose oil-based polyurethane if you…  
   • Want a warm, amber glow that accentuates grain.  
   • Need maximum chemical/abrasion resistance with fewer coats.  
   • Don’t mind a longer dry/cure time or stronger odor.  
   • Are finishing hardwood floors, rustic furniture, tabletops or bar tops.

Tip from the Zava toolbox  
For large floor jobs where you like the look of oil but not the long downtime, a hybrid approach works: one sealer coat of oil-based for color, then two fast topcoats of a compatible water-based polyurethane 24 hrs later. Always do a small test panel first to verify adhesion.

Application essentials  
   1. Stir, never shake, to avoid bubbles.  
   2. Use a high-quality synthetic bristle or microfiber roller for water-based; natural bristle or foam/synthetic blend for oil-based.  
   3. Maintain a wet edge and work with the grain.  
   4. Lightly scuff-sand (220–320-grit) between coats and tack-cloth clean.

Have more questions, or need help picking the right finish for your project? Just ask—Zava’s here to help.

How should I prepare walls before painting?

Preparing interior walls properly is the key to a paint job that looks great and lasts. Here’s a step-by-step guide you can follow with common tools and materials from a DIY hardware store like Zava:

1. Clear and protect the area  
   • Move furniture away from walls or out of the room if possible.  
   • Lay down drop cloths or plastic sheeting to protect floors.  
   • Remove or loosen switch plates, outlet covers, curtain hardware, nails, and picture hangers.  
   • Mask trim, baseboards, and windows with painter’s tape.

2. Clean the surface  
   • Dust first: Wipe walls with a microfiber cloth or use a vacuum with a brush attachment.  
   • Degrease: In kitchens, bathrooms, or around light switches, wash with a mild solution of water and dish soap or a dedicated wall cleaner (e.g., TSP substitute). Rinse with clean water and let dry.  
   • Address mildew: Spot-treat mildew with a 3:1 water-to-bleach solution (wear gloves/eye protection and ensure ventilation).

3. Repair imperfections  
   • Fill nail holes and small dents with spackle or lightweight joint compound.  
   • For larger holes or cracks, use a patch kit or joint compound with a mesh patch.  
   • Let each repair dry fully (check the product’s label), then sand flush with 120- to 150-grit sandpaper.

4. Sand and smooth  
   • Lightly sand glossy or rough areas to create a “tooth” for the new paint.  
   • Feather the edges around patched spots so they blend in.  
   • Remove dust with a damp cloth or tack cloth; walls must be dust-free before priming.

5. Address stains (optional but recommended)  
   • Water, smoke, or marker stains can bleed through paint. Spot-prime or seal them with a stain-blocking primer.

6. Prime (crucial in many cases)  
   • Always prime bare drywall, patched areas, or walls transitioning from dark-to-light colors.  
   • For glossy surfaces (lacquered trim, semi-gloss enamel), use a bonding primer.  
   • Roll and brush primer evenly; allow full dry time.

7. Final checks  
   • Inspect walls for missed dents or rough spots. Touch up, sand, and re-prime if needed.  
   • Ensure the room is well-ventilated and at the temperature recommended on your paint can (usually 50–90 °F or 10–32 °C).

8. Gather paint supplies  
   • Quality roller covers and brushes matched to your paint (e.g., 3/8" nap for smooth walls).  
   • Paint tray, extension pole, and a 5-in-1 tool or putty knife.  
   • Paint key or opener, stir sticks, and a clean, damp cloth for drips.

With these steps complete, your walls are ready for the first coat of paint. Proper prep minimizes flashing (uneven sheen), promotes adhesion, and gives you the smooth, professional finish you’re after. Happy painting!
